Quietly, without flowers or tears, the
much-debated judicial code has been laid to
rest. The heartbreak of rejection proved to
be more than the code could withstand,
and the Student Council finally put it to
sleep this week.
While the Council's action is understandable in light of previous response to
the code, it ultimately goes too far. A
judicial code created by students could
and should govern the process of hearing
student offenses.
Veterans of Homewood have heard
more about the code than they probably
cared to since the initial proposal in 1977,
but for freshmen perhaps a little explanation is in order. The code's chief purpose
was to provide all members of the Hopkins community with a means of pursuing
grievances against students: a corollary aim
of the code was to protect the rights of the
student accused. Key features of the
proposed code were the right of the
accused to have his case heard by either
a board of his peers or by the Director of
Student Services: an appeal process: and
the establishment of a Common Law Log
to maintain juridical precedents.
On the one hand, the Council's
reason for tabling work on the code makes
sense: the code has been shot down twice
in referendum. From their point of view, it
isn't worth it to spend long hours reworking the code only to have it defeated. There
are other matters that need attention. and
at this point, the Council perception is that
the code is doomed to rejection no matter
what changes in it are made. This year, the
code would be up against a particularly

hostile electorate: three of the four classes
have seen it before and sent it packing.
Yet, while the Council's action may
conceivably have the beneficial effect of
bringing to life diehard supporters of the
code, it threatens at present to put the final
knife in the still-twitching document, and
in the end this would be the students' loss.
While there may have been many flaws in
the code which was rejected last year, it
was nevertheless an attempt to protect
students. One misconception about the
document, which may have ultimately
killed it, was that it would actually make
the student liable to a greater variety of
potential criminal charges than he was
before. For example. the code had a
procedure for dealing with offenses committed by the student outside of Hopkins,
and many people believed that prior to the
code the school would never have addressed such offenses. The truth is that the
- University has always had the prerogative
to punish students for such offenses; under
the code, there would simply have been an
established procedure for doing so, one
that might have provided additional safeguards for the student.
In the end, it seems that student
response to the code has been emotional
and uninformed. It would be a shame to
see the focus of so much work completely
tabled. Putting the code aside in the face of
certain rejection makes sense, but attempts
should be made to re-educate the students
on this matter. Eventually, work on the
code should continue. We should support
our own efforts to protect ourselves.
